titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Audiovisual materials FA750

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-04-18 00:00:22 -0400.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Since the audiovisual materials have inherently been separated from other Ford Foundation archival holdings, the description of any individual item, or set of items, may also currently appear, in some form, in the finding aid for the originating collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Contains films, video and audio materials.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in 3 series by file type.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: When requesting to view audiovisual material, please refer to the Title and the AV Number (example: AV 1916). Researchers are asked to check the "Restrictions" note for each Title. If a Title does not currently have an access copy, please contact a RAC archivist for further instruction.

All inquiries to view films require advanced notice of at least 2 business days, and may necessitate notice of up to one week. Individual items, including those that are not available in modern formats, may be restricted from access at the discretion of RAC.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Types of records include: film, audio, and video.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The films included in the collection are the products of various grants and internal initiatives, dating from the early 1950s.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation is a nonprofit grant-making organization with an extensive history of international leadership in economic development, human rights and microfinance, as well as major U.S. causes, including the environment, civil rights, legal aid, and women's rights, and such domestic challenges as urban development and reproductive health.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: When requesting to view audiovisual material, please refer to the Title and the AV Number (example: AV 1916). Researchers are asked to check the "Restrictions" note for each Title. If a Title does not currently have an access copy, please contact a RAC archivist for further instruction.

All inquiries to view films require advanced notice of at least 2 business days, and may necessitate notice of up to one week. Individual items, including those that are not available in modern formats, may be restricted from access at the discretion of RAC.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A documentary about traditional arts and storytelling in southern US communities, with interviews and footage of Eudora Welty, Pecolia Warner, and others. Directed by Bill Ferris. Funded by the Rockefeller Foundation, National Endowment for the Humanities, Mississippi Arts Commission, and the Ford Foundation. Copyright 1977, Center for Southern Folklore.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Access copy currently unavailable. Please contact an RAC archivist for further instruction.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Short film presented by the American Federation of Arts about the physics and characteristics of abstraction. Distorting physical items from science, nature, and intangible items in math and art can all be understood as abstraction. Abstract concepts in design, art, and language are shown. An ACI Release. Produced by Roemer-Young Associates. Ford Foundation grant from 1966 to American Federation of Arts.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See also Ford Foundation grant 06600421 (PA66-421), The American Federation Of Arts, Inc., DEVELOP SIXTEEN ART INSTRUCTION FILMS AND RELATED INSTRUCTIONAL MATERIALS FOR USE IN THE FIFTH GRADE.

scopecontent.p: Episode of TV series from unknown network hosted by Dr. Ron Pion. Features a pregnant woman and a panel of children who are queried about pregnancy and childbirth. Produced by Jeff Shiffman, a King Community Services Program.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Overcrowded prisons and outdated systems in Georgia required the state to explore nontraditional sentencing structures - their successes are documented in this short film. At the threat of federal involvement, the state designed new alternatives to prison time. The film shows several tiers of options for nonviolent criminals, and discusses the challenges and accomplishments of the programs. Funded by the Ford Foundation and the JFK School of Government at Harvard. Produced by David Jordan, copyright 1988 by GDC.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Showcase of education and training opportunities for young people in Nigeria. A four-year study by the American Institute for Research and the US Agency for International Development produced an aptitude test, which was incorporated into school and professional systems throughout Nigeria. Details of the test and its outcomes are presented. This film is presented by the Ford Foundation in cooperation with the public authorities of Nigeria.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An episode of the series "Are You Listening?" featuring women who work as domestic employees and maids. Issues of respect, education, and benefits are discussed from the point of view of the household technician.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Short film presented by the American Federation of Arts about the perception of light, color, shape, and other physical concepts we see. Demonstration of seeing aspects of natural, scientific, and artistic elements. An ACI Release.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Film produced by and about the small Eskimo village of Gambell, on St. Lawrence Island in Alaska. Includes footage of whale hunting, a village-wide activity, as well as singing and dancing, cooking, family relations, and other Eskimo traditions in their general village life. Copyright 1975, the Village of Gambell and Leonard Kemerling.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Documentary film based on the autobiography "Born to Rebel" of Morehouse College president Benjamin E. Mays. Film includes interviews with Dr Martin Luther King Sr., Jimmy Carter, Coretta Scott King, Samuel DuBois Cook, Edward B. Williams and John Danforth. Produced with a grant from the Ford Foundation. Grant # 75-31. Copyright University of Georgia, 1974.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials

scopecontent.p: Demonstrations of political and religious rites of the Oba, or King of the Benin region of West Africa. Footage of the Igua Blessing, Odudna Masquerare, and the Ugie-Erha-Oba Festival, with explanatory narrative. Produced for the Benin Historical Research Scheme by F.E. Speed and R.E. Bradbury.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Film examining post-colonial issues in under-developed nations, as seen by third world residents and their wealthy neighbor nations. Discusses issues of education and access, agriculture and industry, international economics, and the basic struggles of people in need. Written and directed by Richard Broad. Thames Colour Production.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Demonstration of the Tan-Gau method of secondary language instruction, as presented to a a group of Canadian 5th grade students. A teacher from Toronto, Raymond Duplantie, uses the Tan-Gau method to introduce basic vocabulary. Lessons 1 and 2 are shown, based on the work on Dr. Tan-Gwan Leong and Dr. Robert Gauthier. Produced for the Canadian Conference on Education and the Ford Foundation, with the Metropolitan Educational Televisions Association. A CFTO Production.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Documentary about issues in the education system, as demonstrated by schools in Montgomery County, Maryland. Poor communication between staff and students, unequal rights, overly strict polices, etc. are discussed in interviews and montages. "The questions we have tried to raise, and the points of view expressed, mainly reflect the interests of the only group involved in this problem, whose voices won't be heard, that of the students."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Film about the work of the International Committee of the Red Cross in Africa; efforts to provide food, housing, and healthcare for Africans throughout the continent affected by war, civil unrest, and lack of infrastructure. Footage of battlegrounds in Chad, medical camps in Botswana, Rhodesian refugees, interviews with doctors and nurses working in rural clinics, etc. Some graphic footage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Documentary about six American auto workers who spend time in a Saab factory in Sweden to learn about different trends of workplace design and organization. Their program was organized by Cornell University, Industrial and Labor Relations, under a grant from the Ford Foundation. Directed and edited by Peter Goldmann. Produced by Bjorn Ericstam, Sandell. Film, with Executive Producer David Hancock. Copyright maintained by the Ford Foundation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introduction to the US Air Force's plans during the Cold War. The Continental Air Defense Command is introduced during a visit to an underground military base on Long Island, codenamed "COBRA". Anti-Soviet defenses, aviation technology, and national emergency preparedness are discussed. Version is incomplete, film ends suddenly.

scopecontent.p: This film is based on the report and reccommendations of the Ford Foundation project on socil welfare and the American Future. The documentary offeres new ways to think about child care, welfare, the working poor, displaced workers, healthcare, the ederly, addiction issues and homelessness. It was produced for the Ford Foundation by Dick Young Productions, Ltd. New York City. Copyright 1990, Dick Young.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Film report by the Fund for Adult Education, of the Ford Foundation, about an experiment in designing and supporting community leaders. 275 local leaders from all over the United States were invited for a two-week retreat of workshops and discussions on resolving community issues, communication tools, local resources, and other topics. Narrated by John Vacca, the delegate from Odessa, Texas. Filmed at Bigwin Inn in Ontario, Canada.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An introduction to the Continental Classroom film series and its early research in educational TV programming and satellite education. An initial summary of pilot programs precedes Episode 147 of the series,"Nuclear Rhythms", with Dr. Felix Bloch (director of the Manhattan Project). The series was funded by the Ford Foundation, Standard Oil Company of California, the Fund for the Advancement of Education, and many others. Produced by NBC and the American Association of Colleges for Teacher Education.

scopecontent.p: Demonstration of the TAGER system, a closed-circuit educational television program designed to share resources and professors at the university level. Designed by a consortium of Texas universities, including Austin College, Texas Christian University, University of Dallas, and others, the TAGER system formed to unify research and education resources for advanced study, at the graduate level and beyond.

Homeless shelters and programs to help addicts are shown, as well as administrative planning and the new Ford Foundation headquarters in Manhattan. Brief graphic footage of monkeys being inoculated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Short film about environmental management in Erie County, NY. Local officers and citizens worked with the State Department of Environmental Resources, the Department of Sanitation, and the Department of Health to improve water quality and environmental management. Local, ground-level efforts are shown to be more effective than centralized government programs. Produced by John Karol and Apertura, in cooperation with the Erie County Department of Health. Copyright 1976, the Ford Foundation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Film about the Exploratorium Science Museum in San Francisco, CA. Interactive exhibits about light, sound, energy, and other natural phenomena are shown, using optical illusions, kinetic artworks, displays of frequency and pitch, and other methods. The end of the film shows the museum founder, Dr. Frank Oppenheimer, discussing the impact of the exhibits with the staff. This film was shot by Jon Boorstin and funded by the National Education Association and the National Science Foundation. Copyright 1975, Jon Boorstin and the Exploratorium.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Presented by the Pennsylvania State Commission on Industrial this film is a dramatization of desegregation in Bellefonte, Pennsylvania. It is from a white male prepective and he tries to imagine how hard it would be to get a job based on skin color.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A 2-part documentary about issues of housing, taxes, and inequality in the NY region, including NYC and parts of NJ and CT. This episode is the first in a series of "televised town meetings" designed to face issues within the area and encourage civic dialogue. The series, "Choices for 76", was timed to address challenges and solutions in preparation for the Bicentennial of the USA. The series was presented by the Regional Plan Association in the spring of 1973, which published an accompany text entitled "How to Save Urban America", as well as other newspaper and print articles. Produced by David Sawyer and Albert Waller, in collaboration with the US Department of Housing and Urban Development. Funded by a variety of institutions, including the Ford Foundation, Rockefeller Brothers Fund, the Taconic Foundation and Rockefeller Foundation.

did.unittitle: New Images: Art in a Changing African Society

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Access copy currently unavailable. Please contact an RAC archivist for further instruction.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Film discussing the evolution of dance, theater, sculpture, and other traditional fine art practices of the Oshogbo people of Western Nigeria. Made by Francis Speed and Ulli Beier from the University of Ibadan, Nigeria.

The film is a brief description of life in a busy commercial centre that still depends upon and retains its ancient traditions. These are based on the history of the town which was founded on the banks of the river Oshun. This river itself is one of the most important river deities of the Yoruba whose cults spread even as far as Brazil. Aduni Susanne Wenger, a chief priestess of the Obatala cult, is shown rebuilding the once neglected Oshun shrine, with her fellow artists, Adebisi Akanji, OyeWale and Lani. The Beiers show how art based on traditional pagan religion forms the foundation of the modern movement. How painters and sculptors have responded to exposure to modern techniques intelligently and sensitively introduced by Georgina Beier. Oshogbo's vibrant artistic life owes much to the founding of the Mbari Mbayo club by Duro Ladipo, also enthusiastically supported by Twins Seven Seven and Ogunmola. Many of Nigeria's world-renowned artists, play-writes and musicians have passed through Mbari Mbayo's doors. The club also distinguished its self by organizing the exhibition of art from other African regions - something that Ulli Beier was particularly keen to promote. This film presents a unique view of the vibrant, creative life typical of many Yoruba centres during this period. "Yoruba tradition is a living Force."

did.unittitle: We're Ni! He is a Madman

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Access copy currently unavailable. Please contact an RAC archivist for further instruction.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An ethnopsychiatric film of the management of psychiatric disorders by the Yoruba of Western Nigeria for the Human Ecology Fund. Directed by Raymond Prince, MD. Section of Transcultural Psychiatric Studies, McGill University.

The film documents psychiatric disorders and Yerubic medicine in Yeruba, Nigeria. The documentary includes footage of diagnosis, treatment, care of patients, spiritual healing ceremonies, male and female cult practices, and comparisons of traditional Yerubic religion, Islam and Christianity?s relationship to psychiatric illness.

Among the Yoruba, psychiatric disorder is widespread and a set of institutions has been developed to deal with it. There are two basic types of such institutions: firstly, treatment centres managed by herbalists and diviners with specialist knowledge of traditional psychiatric therapy, and secondly, cult groups such as the Gelede masquerade cult for men and the Egun possession cult for women, which provide a setting for the expression of what is otherwise socially unacceptable behaviour. The film shows a number of aspects of both types of institution.
Contains footage of animal sacrifice and female nudity.

did.unittitle: Hanya -- Portrait of a Dance Pioneer

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Documentary on the life and times of Hanya Holm that traces the career of Hanya Holm from Germany in the 1920s through the Broadway stage. As one of the famous four pioneers of modern dance, Hanya was a founding artist in establishing new forms and educational principles in America. Introduced by Julie Andrews and narrated by Alfred Drake, this film features archival footage from the 1930s and 40s, and interviews with Holm and many of her students, including Murray Louis, Alwin Nikolais, and Harold Lang.

Hanya: Portrait of a Pioneer was first presented at Duke University on the 50th anniversary of the American Dance Festival, when Hanya received the Samuel H. Scripps Award for her lifetime achievements in dance. Also in 1985, it won the Grand Prize in the Dance Film Associations Dance on Camera Festival, held in New York.
Executive Producer: Marilyn Cristofori, and Producer/Editor: Nancy Mason Hauser.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access copy available.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Produced by Georgia Department of Corrections. The Alternative to Incarceration program of the Georgia Department of Corrections (GDC) is a systematic approach to planned offender management. It provides effective, productive alternatives to prison by means of a continuum of sentencing options incrementally arrayed with increasing degrees of punishment, control, supervision, and offender services.

GDC's alternative sentencing program has become a model for others throughout the nation. The Georgia program has set the standard, clearly demonstrating that innovative sentencing can be an effective part of the criminal justice system. These options protect the public, punish the criminal, provide restitution to the victim and the community, and offer enormous savings to the tax payer.

Funding for this film was provided by a grant from the Ford Foundation in recognition of the selection of the Georgia Department of Corrections as a winner of the Innovations in State and Local Government Award, a program of the Ford Foundation in collaboration with the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation is a nonprofit grant-making organization with an extensive history of international leadership in economic development, human rights and microfinance, as well as major U.S. causes, including the environment, civil rights, legal aid, and women's rights, and such domestic challenges as urban development and reproductive health.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: WBAI radio discussion regarding the IUD, with Dr. Christopher Tietze (National Committee on Maternal Health), Dr. Gordon Perkin (Planned Parenthood), and Dr. Robert E. Hall (Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons). Topics include: explanation of the IUD; comparison to other forms of contraception; side effects; legal restrictions; religious objections; governmental interest, Planned Parenthood; and the IUD usage in high-population countries.
